title: Extend issue formatter to support full buffer format with YAML frontmatter
description:
The current `format_issue_to_markdown()` function in `lua/nvim-beads/issue.lua` was designed for Telescope preview and may not include all fields required for the editable buffer format.

This task extends the formatter to output the complete buffer format as specified in detailed-requirements.md section 3.2, including:
- YAML frontmatter with all metadata fields (id, title, type, status, priority, parent, dependencies, labels, timestamps)
- Markdown sections (Description, Acceptance Criteria, Design, Notes)

The formatter should produce output that matches the exact format shown in the requirements, with proper YAML delimiters and section headers.
design:
Extend the existing `format_issue_to_markdown()` function or create a new function variant specifically for buffer formatting.

Key implementation details:
- Add YAML frontmatter generation with `---` delimiters
- Include all metadata fields from the issue JSON
- Mark read-only fields with comments (id, created_at, updated_at, closed_at)
- Handle optional fields gracefully (parent, dependencies, labels, closed_at)
- Format arrays properly (dependencies, labels) as YAML lists
- Preserve existing Markdown section generation
- Ensure proper blank line spacing between sections

Reference the JSON schema from bd show output and the buffer format specification in detailed-requirements.md section 3.2.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Formatter outputs valid YAML frontmatter enclosed in `---` delimiters
- [ ] All required metadata fields are included: id, title, type, status, priority, timestamps
- [ ] Optional fields (parent, dependencies, labels) are included when present
- [ ] Dependencies and labels are formatted as YAML arrays
- [ ] Markdown sections (Description, Acceptance Criteria, Design, Notes) follow the frontmatter
- [ ] Unit tests verify correct formatting for issues with various field combinations
- [ ] Unit tests verify optional fields are handled correctly (present vs absent)

title: Implement Save Autocommand Integration
description:
Wire together all the pieces to implement the save workflow for beads:// buffers. When a user saves an issue buffer, the autocommand should parse the buffer, detect changes, execute the appropriate `bd` commands, and reload the buffer with the authoritative state.

This is the orchestration layer that connects the parser, diff logic, and command generation into a working feature.
design:
**Implementation location:** `lua/nvim-beads/autocmds.lua`

**Workflow:**
1. Create `BufWritePost` autocommand for `beads://issue/*` buffers
2. In the callback:
   a. Extract issue ID from buffer name
   b. Get buffer content using `vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines()`
   c. Parse buffer using `parse_markdown_to_issue()`
   d. Fetch original state using `bd show --json <id>` (via core.lua executor)
   e. Diff the states using `diff_issues()`
   f. Generate commands using `generate_update_commands()`
   g. Execute each command sequentially (via core.lua executor)
   h. If all succeed, reload buffer from authoritative source
   i. If any fail, report error to user via `vim.notify()`

**Key considerations:**
- Error handling at each step (parse failure, bd command failure, etc.)
- Preserve cursor position after reload if possible
- Clear modified flag after successful save
- Atomic execution: if one command fails, report error and don't reload

**Testing approach:**
- Minimal integration test or manual testing (unit tests cover the core logic)
- Could mock `vim.api` and core executor for a basic integration test
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `lua/nvim-beads/autocmds.lua` created with `BufWritePost` autocommand
- [ ] Autocommand triggers on `beads://issue/*` pattern
- [ ] Save workflow implemented:
  - [ ] Parses buffer content
  - [ ] Fetches original state from `bd show`
  - [ ] Diffs the states
  - [ ] Generates update commands
  - [ ] Executes commands sequentially
  - [ ] Reloads buffer on success
  - [ ] Reports errors on failure
- [ ] Error handling covers all failure points
- [ ] Manual testing demonstrates:
  - [ ] Editing title and saving updates the issue
  - [ ] Editing status and saving updates the issue
  - [ ] Adding/removing labels works correctly
  - [ ] Adding/removing dependencies works correctly
  - [ ] Editing text sections (description, etc.) works correctly
  - [ ] Buffer reloads with updated content after save
- [ ] Cursor position is preserved after reload (if feasible)

title: Implement Command Generation with Tests
description:
Implement the command generation logic that converts a list of changes (from the diff function) into the appropriate `bd` CLI commands to apply those changes.

This is a pure function that takes the structured changes and generates a list of executable `bd` commands following the CLI mapping defined in the detailed requirements.
design:
**Function signature:** `generate_update_commands(issue_id, changes) -> commands`

**Input:**
- `issue_id`: The issue ID (e.g., "bd-1")
- `changes`: Change table from `diff_issues()`

**Output:** List of `bd` command strings to execute in order

**Command mapping (from detailed-requirements.md):**
- **Metadata/text fields:** `bd update <id> --title "..." --priority N --description "..." --acceptance "..." --design "..." --notes "..."`
- **Status:** 
  - `bd update <id> --status <status>` for in_progress/blocked
  - `bd close <id>` for closed
  - `bd reopen <id>` for open (if previously closed)
- **Labels:**
  - `bd label add <id> <label>` (one per addition)
  - `bd label remove <id> <label>` (one per removal)
- **Dependencies:**
  - `bd dep add <id> <dep-id> --type blocks` (one per addition)
  - `bd dep remove <id> <dep-id>` (one per removal)
- **Parent:**
  - `bd dep add <id> <parent-id> --type parent-child` (if added/changed)
  - `bd dep remove <id> <old-parent-id>` (if removed/changed)

**Implementation approach:**
1. Process changes in order: parent/deps first, then labels, then status, then metadata/text
2. Generate appropriate command strings with proper escaping
3. Return ordered list of commands

**Key considerations:**
- Proper shell escaping for text fields with quotes/special chars
- Handle status transitions correctly (close vs update --status)
- Parent changes may require removing old parent first
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test file created at `spec/nvim-beads/commands_spec.lua`
- [ ] Test cases cover:
  - [ ] Metadata field updates (title, priority)
  - [ ] Text section updates (description, acceptance, design, notes)
  - [ ] Status update to in_progress/blocked
  - [ ] Status change to closed (generates `bd close`)
  - [ ] Status change to open (generates `bd reopen`)
  - [ ] Label additions and removals
  - [ ] Dependency additions and removals
  - [ ] Parent addition, removal, and change
  - [ ] Multiple simultaneous changes generating correct command sequence
  - [ ] Proper escaping of special characters in text fields
- [ ] `generate_update_commands()` function implemented in `lua/nvim-beads/issue.lua`
- [ ] All tests pass when run with `busted`
- [ ] Generated commands match the CLI mapping from detailed-requirements.md

title: Implement issue formatter with full metadata
description: Implement format_issue_to_markdown(issue) function in lua/nvim-beads/issue.lua that converts a bd issue table into a list of strings representing YAML frontmatter followed by Markdown body content.
design:
Function signature: format_issue_to_markdown(issue) -> string[]

Output format must match requirements doc section 3.2 exactly:

```
---
id: bd-1
title: My Issue Title
type: feature
status: open
priority: 2
parent: bd-100
dependencies:
  - bd-120
  - bd-121
labels:
  - ui
  - backend
created_at: 2023-10-27T10:00:00Z
updated_at: 2023-10-27T12:00:00Z
closed_at: null
---

# Description

A clear, detailed explanation of the issue.

# Acceptance Criteria

A list of criteria that must be met for the issue to be considered complete.

# Design

Technical design notes or implementation plan.

# Notes

Any other relevant information.
```

Key requirements:
- Use `type` in frontmatter (not `issue_type` - transform from bd JSON)
- Use single `#` for section headings (not `##`)
- Dependencies go in YAML frontmatter as list (not markdown section)
- Parent is separate frontmatter field (not in dependencies)
- All timestamps use ISO format with Z timezone
- Optional fields: parent, labels, closed_at, assignee, description, design, acceptance_criteria, notes
- Omit empty/null sections entirely
acceptance_criteria:
- issue.lua module exists with format_issue_to_markdown function
- Returns array of strings (one per line) for buffer insertion
- YAML frontmatter uses `type` field (mapped from bd's `issue_type`)
- Section headings use single # (not ##)
- Dependencies list in YAML frontmatter (not markdown body)
- Parent shown separately in frontmatter when present
- Timestamp fields: created_at, updated_at, closed_at
- Optional sections omitted when null/empty
- Function uses types from types.lua
- Output matches requirements doc section 3.2 exactly

title: Create type definitions module (types.lua)
description: Create lua/nvim-beads/types.lua module with type definitions and documentation for issue data structures used throughout the plugin. This will serve as the single source of truth for what fields exist on issue objects.
design:
Create lua/nvim-beads/types.lua with EmmyLua annotations.

Key type definitions needed:

1. **Issue** - Main type matching bd show --json output:
   ```lua
   ---@class Issue
   ---@field id string
   ---@field title string
   ---@field description string|nil
   ---@field design string|nil
   ---@field acceptance_criteria string|nil
   ---@field notes string|nil
   ---@field status "open"|"in_progress"|"blocked"|"closed"
   ---@field priority integer (0-4)
   ---@field issue_type "bug"|"feature"|"task"|"epic"|"chore"
   ---@field assignee string|nil
   ---@field labels string[]|nil
   ---@field created_at string (ISO 8601)
   ---@field updated_at string (ISO 8601)
   ---@field closed_at string|nil (ISO 8601)
   ---@field external_ref string|nil
   ---@field dependencies Dependency[]|nil
   ---@field dependents Dependency[]|nil
   ```

2. **Dependency** - Dependency relationship type:
   ```lua
   ---@class Dependency
   ---@field id string
   ---@field title string
   ---@field dependency_type "blocks"|"related"|"parent-child"|"discovered-from"
   ```

Note: The `parent` field shown in requirements doc frontmatter is derived from dependencies array where dependency_type == "parent-child"
acceptance_criteria:
- types.lua exists in lua/nvim-beads/
- Contains EmmyLua type annotations for Issue and related types
- All fields from bd JSON output are documented

title: Add Telescope action to open issue buffer on <CR>
description:
Enhance the existing Telescope beads_picker in `lua/telescope/_extensions/nvim_beads/init.lua` to handle the default action (Enter key).

When a user presses `<CR>` on a selected issue in the Telescope picker:
1. The picker should close
2. The selected issue should be opened in a new buffer using `open_issue_buffer()`

This provides the primary workflow for navigating from the issue list to viewing/editing individual issues.
design:
Implementation using Telescope's action system:

1. Import required modules:
   - `require('telescope.actions')` for action utilities
   - `require('telescope.actions.state')` for getting selected entry
   - `require('nvim-beads.issue')` for open_issue_buffer function

2. In the beads_picker configuration, add an `attach_mappings` function:
   ```lua
   attach_mappings = function(prompt_bufnr, map)
     actions.select_default:replace(function()
       local selection = action_state.get_selected_entry()
       actions.close(prompt_bufnr)
       require('nvim-beads.issue').open_issue_buffer(selection.value.id)
     end)
     return true
   end
   ```

3. The `selection.value` will contain the full issue object from the finder
4. Extract the issue ID and pass it to open_issue_buffer()

This is a small, focused change to the existing Telescope picker.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Pressing `<CR>` in the Telescope picker closes the picker
- [ ] The selected issue is opened in a new buffer via open_issue_buffer()
- [ ] The correct issue ID is passed to open_issue_buffer()
- [ ] Manual testing confirms the workflow: :Beads -> select issue -> press Enter -> buffer opens
- [ ] Error handling from open_issue_buffer() is preserved (errors display correctly)

title: Create :BeadsOpenIssue command for direct issue buffer access
description:
Add a new user command `:BeadsOpenIssue <id>` that provides direct access to opening an issue buffer without going through the Telescope picker.

This command:
- Takes a single required argument (the issue ID)
- Calls `open_issue_buffer()` with the provided ID
- Provides a faster workflow when the user knows the exact issue ID they want to open

The command should be defined in `lua/nvim-beads/commands.lua` or the appropriate commands module.
design:
Implementation:

1. Define the command using `vim.api.nvim_create_user_command()`:
   ```lua
   vim.api.nvim_create_user_command('BeadsOpenIssue', function(opts)
     require('nvim-beads.issue').open_issue_buffer(opts.args)
   end, {
     nargs = 1,
     desc = 'Open a beads issue by ID in a buffer',
   })
   ```

2. The command should be registered when the plugin loads (likely in plugin/nvim-beads.lua or commands.lua)

3. The `opts.args` will contain the issue ID string provided by the user

4. Error handling (invalid ID, etc.) is delegated to open_issue_buffer()

5. Consider adding completion in the future (post-MVP) to suggest issue IDs
acceptance_criteria:

- [ ] Running `:BeadsOpenIssue bd-123` opens the issue buffer for bd-123

title: Implement open_issue_buffer() to fetch and display issues in beads:// buffers
description:
Create the core buffer manager function `open_issue_buffer(issue_id)` in `lua/nvim-beads/issue.lua` that:
1. Executes `bd show --json <issue_id>` to fetch issue data
2. Formats the data using the extended formatter
3. Creates a new buffer with the naming scheme `beads://issue/<issue_id>`
4. Populates the buffer with formatted content
5. Configures the buffer with appropriate settings (filetype markdown, buffer options)

This function serves as the foundation for opening issues from Telescope and from the user command.
design:
Implementation approach:
1. Use `vim.system()` to execute `bd show --json <issue_id>` asynchronously
2. Parse JSON response and handle errors (invalid ID, command failures)
3. Call the formatter to convert issue data to buffer content
4. Create buffer using `vim.api.nvim_create_buf()`
5. Set buffer name using `vim.api.nvim_buf_set_name()` with `beads://issue/<issue_id>`
6. Set buffer lines using `vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines()`
7. Configure buffer options:
   - `filetype = 'markdown'`
   - `buftype = 'acwrite'` (for custom save handling in future iteration)
   - `bufhidden = 'hide'`
8. Open buffer in current window with `vim.api.nvim_set_current_buf()`
9. Handle errors gracefully with vim.notify

Consider reusing the bd executor function from core.lua if it exists.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Function `open_issue_buffer(issue_id)` exists in lua/nvim-beads/issue.lua
- [ ] Function executes `bd show --json <issue_id>` to fetch issue data
- [ ] Errors (invalid ID, missing bd command) are caught and reported via vim.notify
- [ ] Buffer is created with name `beads://issue/<issue_id>`
- [ ] Buffer filetype is set to 'markdown'
- [ ] Buffer is populated with formatted content (YAML frontmatter + Markdown)
- [ ] Buffer is displayed in the current window

title: Implement Diff Logic with Tests
description:
Implement the comparison/diff logic to detect what changed between the original issue state (from `bd show --json`) and the modified buffer state (from the parser).

This is a pure function that takes two issue tables and returns a structured list of changes, which will be used to generate the appropriate `bd` commands.
design:
**Function signature:** `diff_issues(original, modified) -> changes`

**Input:**
- `original`: Issue table from `bd show --json`
- `modified`: Issue table from `parse_markdown_to_issue()`

**Output:** Table of changes, structured by field type:
```lua
{
  metadata = { title = "new title", priority = 1 },
  status = "in_progress",
  labels = { add = {"ui", "backend"}, remove = {"old-label"} },
  dependencies = { add = {"bd-120"}, remove = {"bd-100"} },
  parent = "bd-50",  -- or nil if removed
  sections = { description = "...", acceptance_criteria = "...", design = "...", notes = "..." }
}
```

**Implementation approach:**
1. Compare each field type separately
2. For labels and dependencies: compute set differences (additions vs removals)
3. For parent: detect add/remove/change
4. For text fields: simple equality check
5. Only include changed fields in output

**Key considerations:**
- Ignore read-only fields (id, timestamps)
- Handle nil/empty values correctly
- Parent changes affect dependencies (parent-child relationship)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test file created at `spec/nvim-beads/diff_spec.lua`
- [ ] Test cases cover:
  - [ ] No changes detected when states are identical
  - [ ] Metadata changes (title, priority)
  - [ ] Status changes
  - [ ] Label additions, removals, and both
  - [ ] Dependency additions, removals, and both
  - [ ] Parent field add, remove, and change
  - [ ] Text section changes (description, acceptance_criteria, design, notes)
  - [ ] Multiple simultaneous changes across different field types
- [ ] `diff_issues()` function implemented in `lua/nvim-beads/issue.lua`
